summary.para: Called when the sample-grabber sink receives a new media sample.

param.name: guidMajorMediaType
param.para: The major type GUID that specifies the format of the data. For a list of possible values, see Major Media Types.

param.name: dwSampleFlags
param.para: Sample flags. The sample-grabber sink gets the value of this parameter by calling the method of the media sample.

param.name: llSampleTime
param.para: The presentation time for this sample, in 100-nanosecond units. If the sample does not have a presentation time, the value of this parameter is _I64_MAX

param.name: llSampleDuration
param.para: The duration of the sample, in 100-nanosecond units.
If the sample does not have a duration, the value of this parameter is _I64_MAX.

param.name: pSampleBuffer
param.para: A pointer to a buffer that contains the sample data.

param.name: dwSampleSize
param.para: The size, in bytes, of the pSampleBuffer buffer.

param.name: pAttributes
param.para: A pointer to the interface. Use this interface to get the attributes for this sample (if any). For a list of sample attributes, see Sample Attributes.

returns.para: If this method succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

remarks.para: If you use the sample-grabber sink in a playback topology, this method should return quickly, or it might interfere with playback. Do not block the thread, wait on events, or perform other lengthy operations inside this method.
This callback interface is used with the sample-grabber sink. It extends the interface by adding the method, which supersedes the method.
The method adds a parameter that contains the attributes for the media sample. You can use the attributes to get information about the sample, such as field dominance and telecine flags.
To use this interface, do the following:

item.description: Implement a callback object that exposes the interface.
Create the sample-grabber sink by calling the function. Pass the callback pointer in the pIMFSampleGrabberSinkCallback parameter.
The sample-grabber sink will call QueryInterface on the callback object.

If the callback object exposes the IMFSampleGrabberSinkCallback2 interface, the sample-grabber sink will use the callback method. Otherwise, the sample-grabber sink will use the older callback method.
